paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy in tumors that are otherwise non-responsive to immune checkpoint inhibitors?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Mice receiving combination therapy of intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 across multiple repeat experiments

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Mice receiving vaccine only, ICI only, or vehicle as matched controls across experiments

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment analyzed retrospectively by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective cohort who had received prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings
